Selected Answer: D
D. Obtain sponsoring organization approval to begin closeout procedures to transition benefits sustainment to the supporting organization.

This step is crucial as it ensures that the program closure is authorized and endorsed by the program's governance structure. It is a formal acknowledgement that the program has delivered the planned benefits and is ready to transition to the next phase, which typically involves the sustainment of benefits by the receiving or supporting organization. The program manager needs to ensure that all the procedures for closing are in line with the governance board's expectations and that the transition of the benefits is planned and executed smoothly. This action reflects the program governance's role in formally closing the program and transitioning its deliverables to the appropriate stakeholders or operations for ongoing benefit realization.

questions.question_text:
A software company's program manager is conducting closing procedures for a program. At the last steering committee meeting, realized benefits were presented to the program governance board.
What should the program manager do next?

choices.B: Initiate knowledge transfer with the receiving organization, and establish the program integration management plan.
choices.C: Update the financial, stakeholder, and contract management plans, and archive them in the program information repository.
choices.A: Begin transitioning program resources, and update the resource and program management plans to reflect the change in the program's status.
choices.D: Obtain sponsoring organization approval to begin closeout procedures to transition benefits sustainment to the supporting organization.

Which program was selected based solely on a three-year return on investment?

After meeting with the program sponsor and stakeholders, the program manager is asked by the sponsor to accelerate the program to replace two legacy financial systems. The legacy systems are at risk of premature failure.
What should the program manager do next?

choices.B: Analyze the impact of accelerating the program, and present the pros and cons to the program sponsor.
choices.D: Create several "what-if" scenarios of alternatives to present to the program sponsor.
choices.A: Accelerate the projects and components of the program that replace the two legacy systems.
choices.C: Identify the parts of the program that need to be accelerated and, if it is cost effective and increases benefits realization, implement the change.

discussion.content: Ans A: Many here seems to have chosen B. I am not sure how B is the right choice. The sponsor already asked the program manager to accelerate to retire the 2 legacy systems. What is the point in again doing some analysis and finding impacts. It is obvious that the 2 legacy systems need to be replaced ASAP. So the focus will be on all the components relevant for that process. Hence my answer is A.

Selected Answer: B
B. Analyze the impact of accelerating the program, and present the pros and cons to the program sponsor.

This action ensures that the program manager performs due diligence by assessing the implications of accelerating the program's timeline. It's critical to understand the potential risks, additional costs, and whether the accelerated timeline would indeed lead to increased benefits realization. Presenting a well-considered analysis to the program sponsor will aid in making an informed decision and planning the next steps accordingly.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct.

questions.question_text:
The program manager has a global program with five component projects. The program sponsor wants the management plans, processes/procedures, and technology to be uniform across the program. The requirements will create issues and result in increased costs The program sponsor is new and has imposed these new requirements six months into a three-year program.
What should the program manager do next?

choices.D: Present the risks and benefits of the changes to the program sponsor.
choices.B: Discuss the proposed changes with the stakeholders and project managers, and give the program sponsor the best option.
choices.A: Accept what the program sponsor requires and implement the changes.
choices.C: Respond to the program sponsor if the program sponsor asks about it a second time.

discussion.content: Ans B: B is the best bet. In fact, D comes from B. B also eventually presents risks and benefits, but first by discussing with stakeholders and project managers. B is also suggesting best options to help make a decision. So my answer would be B.

Selected Answer: D
D. Present the risks and benefits of the changes to the program sponsor.

As a program manager, it is vital to ensure that any significant changes to management plans, processes, or technology are thoroughly evaluated. This includes an analysis of how such changes would impact the program's costs, schedule, scope, quality, and risk. Presenting the risks and benefits of these changes to the program sponsor allows for an informed decision based on a comprehensive understanding of the potential impacts. It is part of the program manager's responsibility to provide this insight to the sponsor before any decisions are made or changes are implemented.
